column4: i never ran into dependency problems with rpm distros as of late.
i think that's just a myth that everyone has kind of stuck with.

It's not quite as common as it was.. but if you upgrade from one rhel version to the next it happens.... especially on certain hardware...  It also happens if you have a webserver running and need a slightly newer version of something... and the rpm isn't available so you do it from source... then use rpm for something that's required by the package later.. it breaks things...
rpm works well for the most part.... yum updates usually are flawless for me as well.. just on occasion it screws up.. but when it does it seems to screw up bad...
